Ah, Twilight Struggle, the game that asks: “What if we took the existential dread of the Cold War and turned it into a two-player migraine simulator?” If you’ve ever wanted to recreate decades of geopolitical tension and mutual paranoia while actively questioning your life choices, this is the game for you.

The premise is simple: One of you plays the USA, the other the USSR, and together you’ll engage in a tug-of-war for global domination. Sounds fun, right? WRONG. What it actually feels like is being trapped in a history textbook written by someone who thinks fun is a capitalist plot.

The card-driven gameplay is equal parts genius and evil. Sure, you get to play powerful events and influence global politics, but more often than not, you’ll draw a hand full of cards that only help your opponent. Want to play a card to advance your strategy? Too bad—enjoy gifting your rival free influence in South America because the game hates you. Nothing screams “fun” like actively sabotaging yourself for an hour.

Speaking of strategy, you’d better love maps and math, because this game is basically Risk’s nerdy cousin who’s obsessed with area control and influence points. Forget epic battles or dramatic twists—this is just spreadsheets on a world map, with the added thrill of nuclear annihilation. It’s less “game night” and more “war college thesis defense.”

And let’s talk about the theme: the Cold War. You know, that famously uplifting period in history where everyone was constantly on edge, nuclear war was a coin flip away, and entire nations were caught in a power struggle between two superpowers. Truly, nothing says “lighthearted entertainment” like reenacting proxy wars and staging coups in Third World countries.

Then there’s DEFCON. This delightful mechanic ensures that one wrong move can escalate tensions and lose you the game outright. Forget strategy; you’re now walking on eggshells, praying you don’t accidentally blow up the planet while trying to score points in Southeast Asia. It’s the board game equivalent of a workplace trust fall, except the stakes are nuclear and everyone’s already mad at you.

Finally, let’s address the playtime. Twilight Struggle markets itself as a “two-hour game,” which is a blatant lie. By the time you’ve explained the rules, argued over the historical accuracy of a card, and tried to figure out why you’re losing, you’ll be three hours deep and begging for the sweet release of mutually assured destruction.

So, if you love games that are stressful, punishing, and leave you feeling like you just failed a history test, Twilight Struggle is perfect. For everyone else, I recommend Patchwork. It’s less historically accurate but way more fun—and there’s no chance of nuking the quilt.

Likewise eurogamers who just aren't going to play Battle Above the Clouds, say, can find this one accessible and interesting. UPDATE: OK, time to clean up my comment here ...

I kinda like Twilight Struggle just for the theme. It's fun to go back and forth and watch the events and get some vaguely historical fun.

But the game has a lot of problems. It's too long for what you get out of it (some commentators have said "quick-playing" is a strength of Twilight Struggle, but at 3 hours I find it wildly overlong for what it is). Several game elements are out of whack. Realignment, for example, is worthless - how does something like this make it into a finished product? Didn't some play-tester say "hey, you know, we never, ever use realignment?". Since the geography of the game largely exists only for realignment, this seems like an issue. And I really dislike how much the game rewards simply knowing the contents of the deck, which makes things unnecessarily hard to learn and needlessly punishing of experience (not skill) differentials.

I could rant on and on about niggling little details like this, stuff that should have been ironed out if GMT had any kind of development process, but the absolute deal-killer here is play-balance. The Soviets are overwhelmingly favored between smart and/or competent players. Sure, I've heard others claim the game isn't unbalanced, but the empirical evidence on my end has now become overwhelming. Once you focus in on the important stuff, paring away all the game elements that don't matter, we haven't seen the US win in 15 games, even playing back-to-back games switching sides, with other players, etc. This is jaw-dropping considering how much luck there is in the game. And I've even found myself pulling punches as the Soviets early in the game, in the hopes of generating a more interesting game and embarrassment of getting to play the hugely favored side, and still winning handily. If the game were anywhere close to balanced you'd think you'd see the US win a few just on pure luck. But no.

Anyway. A frustrating game because with some reasonable development I think it could have been good, even very good; but it's not. I had hopes that 1960: Making of a President might show some improvement, but sadly it seems to have most of the same failings while losing traction on the theme.

UPDATE AGAIN: The evolving rating. Good stuff first. The game is a tight, and mostly fun, area-control/influence game. Each hand becomes a puzzle to be solved, and the game has tons of guessing and bluffing as you try to puzzle out why your opponents is making his plays. It has a neat veneer of a theme with cool cards and a nice looking map.

But the game is problematic in some ways:

THEME: Some parts of the theme feel sort of right. You're balancing investing influence against more aggressive options in order to win a victory without sending the whole world over the edge. The big picture abstractions feel very much like a Cold War-themed game ought to feel. But, and this is a big one, the details are as athematic as a standard Eurogame with take-that cards. What exactly do my cards represent? Does it make any sense temporally to have an event happen every card play? Not at all: I'm just playing out a script when I really want to be engineering a strategy and authoring history. What role am I in? An abstract Geist in a bipolar world? Thematically it feels wrong, and that it is the ultimate deal-breaker for me.

The more I play, the less thematic it becomes, as I start to minmax your hand and wait for events. What does it mean, thematically, to win in a region when only you know that it will be "scored"? It might be sort of fun from a bluffing/gameplay perspective, but it's thematically off. None of this theme stuff really matters. It's a game, so whatever, but no sense in all the fanboy droning about the Cold War "feel"". It's off. Way off.

Gameplay: I'm torn. On one hand it works well. You're walking a knife's edge tug-of-war in a very cool and tense way, but shit there is a lot of randomness to the event draws. A poor draw can really set back one side or the other in a big, perhaps game wasting way. I haven't played nearly enough to really know for sure, but I wonder how much if finally comes down to card-luck and exploiting a good hand. Which is fine, hand-management damage control and hand-exploitation can be a lot of fun, but I'm just not sure that I want that in a game that takes 3+ hours to play.

In Backgammon, the swingyness of the dice balances out over the course of many games; the better player will always win when the law of large numbers kicks takes over. This may be true of TS as well, but at three hours, can one really get in enough games to balance things? I'm fine with screwy card (or dice) luck in a 45 minute game or in a game that is Uber-thematic (ASL for example), but Twilight Struggle sits in weird sorta-themed over-longish middle-ground: too long and inelegant to compete with the best Euros, and too dry and athematic to compete with the best wargames or themers.

As with above, none of this really matters if the game isentertaining, which it mostly has been every time I've played. But #1? Nah,not even close.

While the detail and potential for skilled play are readily apparent, I came out of my first half-dozen games severely let down.
______________________________________________________

The rawness of the tug-of-war system for controlling countries results in a lot of unsatisfying tit-for-tat exchanges during play and the consolidation of so much geopolitical subtlety into abstract Influence Points made TS feel unexpectedly disconnected from its theme. After just a few rounds the Cold War veneer washed away and all I saw was a board of red and blue numbers and a bunch of red and white cards that made the numbers go up or down. It feels gamey.

This unfortunate feeling was deepened by the event system: forcing events of the opposite player to trigger when a card is used for OPs seemed intriguing at first, but it ended up funneling my games of TS into very predictable, constrained lines of play. With almost every event being forced to go off sooner or later, and with player's having such limited agency in their three actions (really two, accounting for the dubious balance of realignment), it just didn't seem possible to have any drastic narrative departures, and the overall game-feel was one of complete mercy to the deck.

Not only does this make TS's narrative arc too scripted for my tastes, but it also means that high levels of play in TS seem dependent on deck memorization and careful maneuvering around the specific requirements of your opponent's events, rather than on more general tactics. Encouraging this type of hyper-detailed foreknowledge is personally unsatisfying as a player, but also undermines TS's thematic bedrock: that the Cold War (to the best of my understanding) was a cultural epoch defined largely by crippling uncertainty.
______________________________________________________

Most of all though, I heavily dislike the type of dice randomness that TS employs. The probabilities of each roll are completely transparent and drama-less, and the only two possible outcomes for any scenario usually boil down to a painfully binary yes or no. If you roll badly on a space-race discard, you just don't make any progress at all (cause everybody knows rocket scientists are prone to all-or-nothing theatrics). If you roll badly on a Quagmire/Bear Trap check, you just don't play the game until you roll better. The dice don't become a source of tactical reassessment or granular risk management, they just say "sorry" and tell you to try again. Coups are the notable exception to this, as the rewards gained are determined by the strength of the roll, something I wish more effects in TS would have emulated.

With the combination of so many binary die rolls and the variance in the card deck, the likelihood of playing a non-game of TS seems to be worryingly high. Someone got all the neutral 4-OP cards the first time through the deck, or someone had to sit out for four (or nine in one of our games) rounds due to Quagmire, or just the right scoring cards randomly came back out of the late war deck to favor one player over another. I'm sure that in the aggregate, strong TS players win more often than not, but this level of wild unpredictability is not easy to accept when games can be 3+ hours long, and having it rear its head in such a small sample of games is very concerning.
______________________________________________________

One last gamey nail in the coffin: having the active player be the sole loser in the event of Nuclear Holocaust is ridiculous. It creates insane incentives for one player to enact mutually assured destruction on their opponent's turn if possible because even if you pull the trigger on humanity-ending Armageddon, you can still die a winner off a technicality.

Having finally played a few card-driven games, I've come to enjoy this style pretty well. I like the tension of deciding how best to use each card, each hand. I like the headline phase in the beginning, the space race track, the pseudo-deckbuilding element as you try to weed out your opponent's powerful events when they'll be least useful. The area majority core is set up a little strangely, but still totally understandable. Even the scoring cards, which can be a kind of wrench in things by showing up at random, I don't have a problem with. So long as you know what's coming & what's already happened, you know where to focus your attention.

Where TS loses me is in most of the rest of the game systems. First off, the defcon track. This thing may be thematic, but it's also a huge pain. It feels like a major portion of the game is just managing this one element and trying to make sure you get the first turn when it's low enough for you to pull off the move you want. Having to remember these bizarre restrictions about where you can and can't do these particular actions is always a nuisance. And that's before you get to the fact that you can end the game prematurely by forcing your opponent to push it to 0. I find this both anti-thematic and un-fun, and dislike that rule intensely.

The military ops track is another piece of chrome that I think could've stood to be cut. I never remember to try and meet that requirement, most of the time you exceed it w/out even trying, and it seems to serve only to encourage you to do coups even more than you ordinarily would (more on that below). I just have no idea why it's even there.

Lastly, though, is the big thing: the action balance. I've played this one several times with the experienced players, the ones who do this every week. Now, you can do 4 things with a card. You can attempt a coup or do a realignment, using the die. You can play the event, or you can just use it to put out influence. The people who know what they're doing seem to stick with just 2 of those: coups and events. Events are self-explanatory, if those are good you'll want to use 'em. But it really feels to me like you want to be using coups at every opportunity, as they're just stronger than the other 2 options. Realignments sound cool, but I've rarely seen them be useful. It would be one thing if coups were locked off by defcon restrictions, but the weaker realignments weren't, but as it is, there's not much reason to use them. Placing out influence is likewise fine, but a very expensive way to break up control, limited by adjacency so you can't always reach the spot you want, and then the next turn your opponent can come along and stage a coup, undoing all your work.

In the end, it's this repetitive feeling of how the game plays (plus the general clunkiness and length) that really gets to me, and makes me wish I were playing something else.

It is a good mix of Euro and wargame mechanics, but my main issues were:
Game length - it's seems like playing 7 out of a hand of 8 cards each turn is excessive; trimming this down could have shortened the game significantly with the same epic feel.

Most wargames are a much closer simulation of what happened, with a mixture of scripted actions and player decisions. After a good wargame, I want to go read about how the battle actually went historically to see how it differs from what happened. Twilight Struggle does not really produce this narrative, since the game is just a string of events and operations, that only very loosely fit the normal timeline through the structure of the 3 section draw deck. I kept wanting to see the alternative event occur a la Chrononauts - it would have been so cool if each event had 2 possibilities - one if played by US, alternative if played by USSR.

2 player area control with # tiles is pretty boring - ultimately the game is area control, with you vying for majority in each country. # tiles are intrinsically less interesting than piles of cubes a la El Grande, and when it's just 2 players, it creates a tug of war where you add 2, I add 3, you take away 2, I take away 1. Oh, how I've eyed you, Twilight Struggle: a game that is undeniably an excellent and carefully-designed Euro-Wargame hybrid that once stood at the top of the BGG top 100 and whose unique blend of mechanisms could excite gamers from near and far. Unfortunately, while I can recognize the potency of the incredibly compelling historical narratives and emergent stories that are produced by this game, I can't find myself interested enough in the core mechanisms to justify devoting the time and attention that they deserve. It's a game that does so many wonderful things - creating tense and difficult moments of hand management and anxiety that really evoke the tension of the Red Scape era - but whose rough edges make the game highly dependent on memorization and study, which is not something I look forward to in my games. The game certainly manages to highlight the history of the Cold War, and its abstraction of the spreading influence of Western Democracies versus Eastern Communism is implemented in a way that remains approachable and understandable. In fact, I found myself surprised by just how clean and simple the core system is that structures the game - it's a game whose complexity certainly emerges from exploring the design long enough to identify the sharp edges and interaction of the many, specific events that are spread throughout the deck. Unfortunately, outside of the card play and my appreciation for the cleanness of the influence system, I find myself more critical of the design in the places where thematic and historic accuracy were preferenced over more transparent and mechanically clean designs. It does make me wonder what the purpose of such a design should be: to tell a compelling story which is adjacent to the actual history but tied to it by the same core events or to legitimately propose an alternate history based on the potential developments and tensions of the time, removing focus on specific events and instead on the interactions of influence, power, etc. In this way, I find games like Pax Pamir 2e, which focus on and celebrate the historic realities and zeitgeists more than the specific actualized events, to be more compelling implementations of pseudo-historic narratives. This makes me far more critical of the randomness and luck in Twilight Struggle - especially when considering the incredibly-consequential and RNG-heavy coup and realignment systems - and it really does take away from the things about the game that are mechanically interesting (instead favoring thematic, emotional responses). Couple this RNG-heavy gameplay with an intense need to memorize many of the key, game-changing events that could be in the deck over the course of the game's often long playtime, and I'm faced with a design that, while respectable, is just so much less interesting to me than other card-driven games out there. I can see why this game is well-appreciated and can understand where folks find it to be compelling, but I'm personally conflicted - I think it's such an interesting system filled with choices, strategy, and subterfuge, but it's also a system that seems far more fun to think about than to actually play. So for me, it's one I'll pass on for now. But who knows - there's always value in looking back later in life. Until then!

Twilight Struggle was an interesting experience - not bad, but not something that completely amazed me. The game unfolds slowly, with a steady progression of events that create a certain dramatic arc. However, what surprised me the most was how much it feels like a competitive, strategic puzzle rather than a historical simulation.

At its core, the game revolves around hand management and optimization. Each turn, players analyze their hand, trying to use their events and action points as efficiently as possible. Success depends less on reacting to a simulated historical narrative and more on mastering the card interactions and planning optimal moves. A player familiar with the deck has a significant advantage over a newcomer, as understanding key events and anticipating card cycles is crucial. Advanced players will even count cards, anticipate reshuffles, and engage in bluffing tactics.

The game’s theme is well-integrated, and the mechanisms make sense within the Cold War setting. Unlike many modern Eurogames, it is highly interactive - every move directly impacts the opponent. This creates an intense psychological battle filled with tension, where small advantages can be decisive. Every turn matters, every action is meaningful, and the game remains tight.

Despite its depth, the rules are not overly complex; the basics can be learned in about 20 minutes. Given that a single session can easily last three hours, this poses a practical challenge. The game demands a dedicated and evenly matched opponent, making it less accessible for casual play.

Ultimately, while Twilight Struggle is an engaging and well-designed game, I find myself wondering whether I would prefer something either shorter and more accessible or, conversely, something more narrative-driven and immersive, like Here I Stand. The game’s strong competitive focus and length make it difficult to fit into everyday gaming situations, which might limit its appeal for me in the long run.

Absolutely no argument - this is an incredible bit of design. For some, this game will slip into the brain without touching the sides, while for others - most notably me - this will feel a rather convoluted, muddy and painful experience. For one, the hand sizes are too large with cards flooded with text and somewhat complex game interactions each twisting the board state based on unique caveats and exceptions, that only many, many games will bring clarity to. For two, even ignoring the events, each other action - placing influence, coups and realignment comes with quite a heavy number of restrictions to remember even before you figure out why you would pick one over the other. For three, for such a strategically deep game an awful lot hinges on the luck of the dice and I'm afraid I simply can't get past the fact that a plan you have agonizingly put together can be completely wrecked by a bad roll. For four, the area control scoring is inelegant and unintuitive - I simply don't enjoy how it works at all, especially when you appear to be smashing it in an area and it turns out you both end up with 3 points each. Finally, for four, I really didn't find the stress of what to do with a card that is basically boils down to YOU LOSE remotely fun.

I get it; this is very much a game about analyzing your hand for the worst cards and figuring out how and when to play them for minimal pain. But personally, I don't find that enjoyable or interesting. Games should be about agonizing over which exciting option would be best, not which is the least worst.

This really is a game for people who are going to get absolutely stuck into it and drink in everything it has to offer. If you were hoping to dig it out casually here and there as part of a heavy rotation of other games, forget it. I so wanted to love it, and in another life maybe I would have. Just a good, involved game. Easy to see why this once held the top spot on the BGG ranks (yes, self-selection in audience played an enormous role as well; that's a prerequisite but not sufficient for such a lofty position).

It's far from a light game, but for the multifaceted gameplay it delivers, it's intuitive and flows well. Exactly two cards' events rankle me from a design perspective, and only some moments of "you do something and I immediately reverse it" seem a touch perfunctory. Otherwise, the freedom the game gives you to activate OPs, as well as the emergent considerations on timing and execution of the game's actions, is fascinating. Even something as subtle as maintaining control over the positioning of the DEFCON track can be a powerful way to influence the game state obliquely, which layers the interaction and strategic considerations.

And the history is just recent enough that, even for the portions that occurred before I was born, parents and grandparents lived through them, and so we grew up in the shadow of them. The Cold War wasn't an omnipresent threat for us, but we sensed the collective import of this nebulous tug-of-war. The game captures this.

It threatens to be too event-heavy, but at least some of this is enemy events in your hand that you don't want to see happen. So when and how you maneuver around them (and when you decide to bite the bullet and activate them) provides painful (i.e. fun) loss-aversion decisions to mix with those where you gain benefits.

I can see how this sort of became the thesis statement for CDGs (card-driven wargames), which some others have iterated on, tried to imitate, or tried to pare down into shorter forms, with varying levels of success. It's a lot of the tensions of that genre done right, plus some cursory touches from Eurogames that undoubtedly broadened the audience a bit compared to its forebearers like Washington's War. The scope (global) and scale (decades) abstracts a lot that might seem more personal or visceral in others that cover only a single battle or more bounded war. But it can hardly be faulted for delivering this grandiose pseudo-conflict so thoroughly. I can't call it my favorite CDG, but can easily see how it's the favorite of many, and were I to invest in enough additional sessions, it could climb to the same heights for me.
